function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Limited quantitative studies in biophilic design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Difficulty in quantifying environmental psychology factors","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Limited evaluation criteria for non-physical architectural themes","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration of specific user groups in biophilic design may lead to inadequate health and well-being outcomes for certain individuals.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Inadequate quantification of exposure time to nature and contact frequency may result in suboptimal biophilic design outcomes.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Lack of scientific substantiation and quantitative evaluation in biophilic architecture may lead to unverified design concepts and ineffective implementation.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-low"},{"name":"Structural problems and excessive humidity caused by plants in architecture","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Insect troubles and odour issues caused by plants in architecture","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Intensive energy use and maintenance required for highly artificial ’green’ designs","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Lack of consideration for air quality in biophilic design may lead to the spread of airborne diseases.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Neglecting proper maintenance of plants in buildings can lead to the propagation of pests and disease-carrying insects.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration for the selection of indigenous plant species may disrupt the local ecosystem and increase the risk of invasive species and diseases.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Integration of ’nature’ into buildings may create conditions for the propagation of contagious diseases.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of diversity in biophilic design practices","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of integration of subfields in architectural research","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Contested and ambiguous notion of ’nature’ in biophilic design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Misunderstanding of culture and context leading to inappropriate information or abuse","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"A sense of loss evoked when designs change negatively or are demolished","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Complex architectural shapes requiring higher budgets","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inevitable human error in mimicking nature may cause an unbalanced system","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Disputes exist between unprocessed, crafted, and synthetic natural materials","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Biophilic design elements leading to excessive uncertainty and controversy","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-low"},{"name":"Overlap and repetition of biophilic design elements","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Insufficient investigation of architectural design issues such as form, typology, scale, proportion, and technology","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of proper ventilation and air quality control","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Limited access to natural habitats for animals","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design could potentially contribute to the spread of contagious diseases through the creation of habitats for animals in urban areas.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of appropriate water management in biophilic design could lead to the proliferation of disease-carrying vectors such as mosquitoes.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design may not be effectively implemented in sustainable architecture","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Disagreement on the interpretation of challenges in sustainable architecture","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Variable contribution of architecture to different sustainable development goals sdgs","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Contagious diseases spread in built environments","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Overlaps and repetitions in biophilic design elements may lead to confusion in interpretation and implementation.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Diverse nature attributes and their classification in architectural design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Divergent elements in nature-based architectural design theories","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Psychological experience of nature in architectural design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguous terminology around ’experience of space and place’ and its relation to contact with nature","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Overlap and ambiguity in the categorization of nature-related elements in the frameworks","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Requirement for specific arrangements for producing pleasurable experiences in nature-related spaces","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Close contact in congested areas may facilitate the spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate ventilation and air quality may increase the risk of airborne disease transmission.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of natural elements and outdoor exposure may impact mental health and immune function.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design may be misinterpreted or misapplied, leading to ineffective implementation of nature-based elements in architecture.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Inadequate incorporation of nature-based elements in architecture may result in a lack of human-nature connection and reduced well-being for building occupants.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Failure to consider the cultural and ecological context of natural elements in biophilic design may lead to insensitivity or disconnection with the local environment and community.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguity in the definition of ’natural spaces’ and ’biophilic design’ may lead to inconsistent interpretation and implementation.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of clarity in taxonomies of ’nature’ in the frameworks may result in misinterpretation and inappropriate application of biophilic design principles.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Differences in interpretations and frameworks may lead to conflicting design approaches and criteria for biophilic design in practice.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dependence on ’nature’ for survival leading to potential contamination and spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Negative psychological effects of certain ’nature’ elements , fear of snakes, spiders leading to mental health impacts.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"}]}
